awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Effects of Air Turbulence and Snowflake Morphology on Snow Fall Speed
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerical weather models contain built-in assumptions for the fall speed of raindrops and snowflakes.  For raindrops, the fall speed is relatively well-constrained near terminal velocity.  However, snowflakes can have very complex patterns allowing them to tumble, spin, and collide with other flakes.  The result is that forecast models have a difficult time predicting snowflake fall speed, affecting the projection of accumulations on the ground.  This award will make use of advanced techniques used in the fluid dynamics community to measure snowflakes in real-world settings and in the laboratory, and use this data to improve numerical weather models.  The main societal benefit of the work will be the potential for better weather forecasts, especially for winter weather events that have significant safety and economic impacts.  The project also focuses on education and training, and a special public outreach event is planned in coordination with the Minnesota Winter Carnival.

The overarching goal of this project is to develop a predictive understanding of the effects of snowflake morphology and atmospheric turbulence on the fall speed of snow.  The research team will study the physical mechanisms controlling snowflake fall speed in atmospheric flows with a combination of field campaigns and laboratory experiments, and will evaluate the impact of such mechanisms on snowfall predictions.  Field observations will take place at a research station in southern Minnesota, where natural snowflake motion will be obtained by Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV), trajectory of snowflakes will be reconstructed by Particle Tracking Velocimetry (PTV), and the morphology of snowflakes will be quantified by Digital In-line Holography (DIH).  Laboratory experiments will be conducted in a custom instrument with 256 air jets that are able to generate turbulent flow.  Synthetic snowflakes, manufactured by 3D printing, will enter the instrument and similar PIV and PTV techniques would be used to capture their motion.  Finally, the data will be used to develop parameterizations which will be integrated into a bulk microphysics scheme in WRF and assessed through simulations and comparisons to observations.  The work plan is derived to answer the following three main research questions: 1) Which aspects of the snowflake morphology are most influential for the snow fall speed?  2) What is the effect of ambient turbulence on the fall speed of a snowflake of given morphology? 3) What is the effect of snowflake fall speed on cloud system characteristics and predicted snowfall?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to the study of snow settling in turbulent flows using laboratory and field measurements. Snow fall speed was observed to strongly depend on both snow morphology, directly affecting drag and weight, and the intensity of the ambient turbulent flow. The most commonly observed snow morphological types are classified as dendrites, graupels, plates, needles and aggregates.

The main outcomes are listed here:

1) Graupel and aggregates tend to behave as inertial particles of near spherical shape. The settling velocity is observed to be enhanced when the Stokes number is near one, i.e. when preferential sweeping  occur (Nemes et al.  J. of Fluid Mech. 814, 2017, Li et al. J. of Fluid Mech. 929, 2021) and snow particle clusters and voids are detected (Li et al. J. of Fluid Mech. , 912, 2020). In such particular conditions, snow particles are accelerated around the downward side of the many small vortices present in atmospheric turbulence and their fall speed becomes, on average, larger than in quiescent air.

2) Plates and dendrites are expected to behave as disk of different thickness and therefore are observed to fall in different ways including tumbling and fluttering depending on their rotational inertial properties (Tinklengberg et al. J. of Fluid Mech. 962, 2023)

3) Density and morphological characteristics of falling snow must be measured to correctly predict the settling velocity of snow in both quiescent and turbulent airflows. We developed an instrument based on Digital-Inline-Holography integrated with a high precision scale that can be deployed in the field and allow the classification of frozen hydrometeors and the estimate of their geometrical and inertial properties (Li et al. J. of Geophys. Res: Atm, 2023).

4) Snow settling velocity was first measured using a planar imaging system and then extended to a full three-dimensional velocity field, using Particle Tracking Velocimetry (Bristow et al. Exp. in Fluids, 64, 2023)

5) A dataset of snow measurements at UMore Park (Rosemount, Minnesota) has been collected, based on our results from more than 20 field deployments from 2017 to 2022.  We plan to make it available to the community using the Univ. of Minnesota data repository.

In summary, the accurate prediction of snow accumulation on ground (how much and where exactly) is significantly challenged by the variability in snow fall velocity. Accurate precipitation forecast must thus be matched by accurate snow morphology and settling velocity prediction. A formula accounting for varying snow morphology and air turbulence is within reach.
